hi, Gordon
  thanks for your suggestions.
  I check my frontier report,  bu=
t still don't know how to solve this 
   problem.    
  can you tell me any=
 details about how to  clean   Snoozed queues  . 
                

--- In =
archive-crawler@yahoogroups.com, Gordon Mohr <gojomo@...> wrote:
>
> Interp=
reting this material:
> 
> Of the 6,456 queues that ever existed during you=
r crawl, 6,444 have
been 
> emptied/completed.
> 
> 12 remain, and among th=
em are 11,781,711 URIs. (It's always the big 
> sites that are still being =
crawled at the end!)
> 
> At the moment of this report, all 12 queues were =
'snoozed' -- pausing 
> either to be polite to the target server, or to wai=
t a reasonable
amount 
> of time to retry a connection-failure.
> 
> You wo=
uld have to look at the logs and individual queues to know which 
> is whic=
h. (A queue snoozing for a few seconds at a time and still 
> leaving succe=
sses in the crawl log is just being polite; a queue 
> snoozing for minutes=
 at a time and only leaving connect-errors in the 
> local-errors.log is ho=
pelessly retrying an unresponsive web server.)
> 
> No evidence of a proble=
m here, just the usual 'tailing off' of activity 
> when only the large, sl=
ow, and dead hosts still have URIs left to
crawl. 
> The URIs left may also=
 be trap/spam/junk/redundant material of 
> negligible value, so based on y=
our analysis of their value to you it
may 
> just be time to end the crawl.=

> 
> - Gordon @ IA
>
